posts.name: Shai
posts.cooked:
Hi, I recently had a look at the specs of the RoboRio and noticed that surprisingly they are very low to the point where my 150$ Samsung smart watch is more powerful. I mean it is extremely unrealistic to pay 485$ for a device with a 2 core 866 MHz processor and only 512 MB of DDR3 memory in 2023… and yes while it is very convenient to have all the IO ready to go such as DIO / PWM ports and CAN Bus, but as much as I know that’s nothing you can’t do with a Rasberry Pi, which gives a significantly more powerful processing power & for a cheaper price.

I guess what I’m trying to ask is whether it is possible to format an rpi to be recognized by the FMS and basically behave exactly like the RR and if there aren’t some rules stating you have to use a Roborio. And maybe even someone has done it before?

posts.name: Lavi Arzi
posts.cooked: You have to use a Roborio according to the rules. In 3 minutes you’ll have the exact rule cited by someone else here.

posts.name: Shai
posts.cooked: yup found it. 9.7 R701 states *Control the ROBOT with a roboRIO. ROBOTS must be controlled via 1 programmable NI roboRIO or roboRIO 2.0 (P/N am3000 or am3000a, both versions referred to throughout this manual as “roboRIO”), with image version 2023_v3.1 or later.

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked:
TapChap:

I mean it is extremely unrealistic to pay 485$ for a device with a 2 core 866 MHz processor and only 512 MB of DDR3 memory in 2023…

While the raw processing power of the roboRIO is underwhelming for the price at first glance, the cost is mainly in its electrical protection features and especially the FPGA which enables the large amount of IO on the board capable of doing things like reading PWM and encoder signals.

I definitely think there’s room for improvement and I’m disappointed the price has only gone up since its introduction in 2015, but there’s a reason we’ll still be using it 10 years later. At the end of the day, it’s not too much harder to add a coprocessor to the robot if you need more power.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: You can definitely use a pi or other processor for any offseason projects or mini bots that won’t play on an official field. While I imagine its possible to get a pi to work with your driver station for a practice bot or something, I’m a mechanic mentor with the software abilities of a typical orangutan.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: There is a WPILIB image for Raspberry Pi and, while it’s not intended for use with FMS, it is used in Romi .

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
You are required by the rules to use a RoboRIO, and the RoboRIO must be capable of shutting off all your motors.

As for the pricing of the RoboRIO with respect to the hardware specs (which the RIO 2 improved slightly), obviously the performance is underwhelming, but I think people overstate how overpriced it is. The RoboRIO gives you a number of things that no cheap, off-the-shelf system completely emulates:

An integrated and rugged package.

Hardware support for many different communication protocols, including crucially CAN

Many easy to use inputs and outputs.

Real Time OS support provided by the vendor

Supported by the vendor for use in FRC

I can imagine hacking together a system with a Raspberry PI and Arduino that would match most of the capabilities of the RoboRIO, and it would probably cost ~$150. However, I’d imagine if I were starting a company to sell a RoboRIO replacement (rules not withstanding), I wouldn’t end up too far from the price tag of the RIO.

If you’d like to have a stronger processor the advice for FRC is to offload parts of your processing to coprocessors. Common choices in FRC right now are Beelink, Jetson, OrangePI, and Raspberry Pi. Some teams have tried to offload as much processing as possible away from the RIO. Team 900 and Team 971 are good teams to look at to see cutting edge FRC compute architectures, but it’s not necessarily a good idea to emulate them.

Ultimately, I like a suggestion I’ve seen on CD that when the control system is next overhauled, compute should be opened up and only the radio should be custom and locked down. But I don’t know whether the path to that is realistic.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
bovlb:

it is used in Romi .

For that, doesn’t the code run on the driver station computer in simulation, and then the outputs communicated to the PI over the network?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Max_Morehead:

For that, doesn’t the code run on the driver station computer in simulation, and then the outputs communicated to the PI over the network?

Yes, but there’s nothing really stopping us from deploying code to it, other than resources to do the last few bits (hardware IO, NetComm equivalent, and deploy support), as we already compile WPILib for the Pi (to support vision processing).  But running code is only the software… the hardware is the more critical and expensive bit.

The capabilities of the Rio from an IO and robustness perspective are substantially better than any low-cost coprocessor board like a Pi.  That comes at a cost (custom board design, injection-molded housing, lots of extra parts for buffers, etc).  As an example, 12V can be connected to any exposed metal on the Rio without damaging it (a rail might go down temporarily, but it will recover without damage once 12V is removed).  I know of teams who are still using the same Rio that they received in the KOP in 2015.  Capability wise, the Rio’s FPGA offers unique capabilities and flexibility (e.g. the WS2812 LED control capability was added in ~2020 with no hardware change). The price point is a little higher than somewhat similar controllers like the VEX V5 brain or REV Control Hub, but it also offers substantially higher capability.

That being said, the utility of the IO capabilities to most teams is substantially lower today than it was when the Rio was introduced.  Most teams are using CAN motor controllers, hooking up sensors to the motor controllers or directly to CAN , and not using any of the RoboRIO IO other than CAN (and maybe a SPI for a gyro and a PWM to drive a LED strand).  This does raise questions regarding what the next robot controller iteration should look like.  Robustness is clearly still very important, but IO requirements might be able to be traded against processing capability.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
We are still using the Alpha version of the Rio on robots.  And a beta version MAY have made its way onto a practice bot.

They are very very durable, and I’m happy to pay the price to have something this bulletproof.

posts.name: Crystal
posts.cooked:
TapChap:

I mean it is extremely unrealistic to pay 485$ for a device with a 2 core 866 MHz processor and only 512 MB of DDR3 memory in 2023…

A roboRIO is not a personal computer. Thinking of its cost in those terms is just silly. It’s like saying “why does this dining room table cost $1000, the wood to make it only costs $150”.

It’s unrealistic to pay $1000 for a laptop to write messages when I can get a stamp for $0.63 and find a pen on the street.

On a completely unrelated note, does CD have a mailing address that accepts replies?

Dear CIM, :heart: Regards, Vasista

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Just to clarify for the peanut gallery:

It’s unrealistic to pay $500 for a RoboRIO when an Arduino will do the same thing for $50 (including case and power). Now that we’re comparing apples to apples…

…Will the Arduino stand up to the same conditions as the RoboRIO? Vibration, dust, dirt, staying on for years or decades at a time, misuse by random workers, random nasty power? (Or, in the specific case of the MyRIO family that the RoboRIO is derived from, random misuse by students in an “educational” environment?)

I think the better way to put it is: You’re not paying for the processor etc. You’re paying for the armor so it has a chance of surviving getting speared by somebody’s gripper.

posts.name: Blake Bourque
posts.cooked:
CHeckout VMX-PI from Kauai Labs. Its a Pi-4b packaged up to serve as “real-time Robotics Controller or Vision/Motion Processor with embedded IMU & CAN-bus interface”

As predicted by others, it is at the ~$400 price point.

posts.name: Guy
posts.cooked: I spilled a can of soda on our 2019 robot (including the RIO and the PDP) and everything still worked

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked:
Adding onto this (perhaps @Peter_Johnson can confirm), I recall there being pretty substantial safety concerns around running full scale FRC hardware using ROMI software.

Something along the lines of the many safety nets that are in place with a proper RoboRIO + DriverStation setup (to ensure hardware disables when it’s supposed to, like in an E-stop condition), not being in place with the Romi/Pi setup.

For the Romi specifically, this is ok as the robot is so small nothing overly bad can happen if things go haywire. It’s a much bigger issue when dealing with 150lb+ machines.

*Note that I’m mostly a hardware/mechanical guy, I could be completely mistaken in the above…

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
cad321:

Something along the lines of the many safety nets that are in place with a proper RoboRIO + DriverStation setup (to ensure hardware disables when it’s supposed to, like in an E-stop condition), not being in place with the Romi/Pi setup.

For the Romi specifically, this is ok as the robot is so small nothing overly bad can happen if things go haywire. It’s a much bigger issue when dealing with 150lb+ machines.

That’s correct, the protocol we use to talk between the sim and the Romi is TCP (websockets), and doesn’t have the disconnect timeout or e-stop protections the real DS (or DS protocol) has.  With the Romi, that’s fine as there’s not enough motor power or mass for safety to be a concern (e.g. about the worst that can happen is it drives off the edge of a table).

posts.name: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!
posts.cooked: As others have alluded to, the Rio has some very specific FRC ‘designed in’ functions that are specifically there to cover safety concerns.  Considering the financial returns on investment, NI has certainly given us a great controller with all of the features required by FIRST engineering to give us a robust and safe platform.  One of those is the ability to cease all movement on the robot regardless of how it is controlled.  That feature has prevented many a participant from injury.
posts.display_username: Al Skierkiewicz  Learn Something New, Every Day!

posts.custom_user_title: Chief Robot Inspector   Learn Something New, Ever Day!

posts.cooked: Just slap a Rio on with a CANivore on “enable-only” and then a CANivore on a high end chip somewhere which can do your real control and you’re good to go for compliance how you want to handle communications and such idk up to you. But yes Rio processing power is kinda crappy compared to any modern hardware since it wasn’t really built for intense compute at any level.
